qas.question: What are the most powerful class of anti-inflammatory drugs?
Low doses of anti-inflammatories are sometimes used with what classes of drugs?
What are two examples of cytotoxic or immunosuppressive drugs?
What is an example of an immunosuppressive drug that prevents T cell activity by altering signal transduction pathways?
What is used to enhance the effects of inflammation?
What are the least powerful anti-inflammatory drugs?
What is not a side effect of glucocorticoids?
What are higher doses of anti-inflammatory drugs used with?
What drugs help T cells respond to signals correctly?

context: <b4_0>Anti-inflammatory drugs<b4_0/> are often used to control the effects of inflammation. <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b5_0>Glucocorticoids<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> are the most powerful of these drugs; however, these drugs can have many undesirable side effects, such as central obesity, <b6_0>hyperglycemia<b6_0/>, osteoporosis, and their use must be tightly controlled. Lower doses of anti-inflammatory drugs are often used in conjunction with <a1_0><a1_1>cytotoxic or <b7_0>immunosuppressive<a1_1/> drugs<b7_0/><a1_0/> such as <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>methotrexate or azathioprine<a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>. <a1_2>Cytotoxic drugs<a1_2/> inhibit the immune response by killing dividing cells such as activated T cells. However, the killing is indiscriminate and other constantly dividing cells and their organs are affected, which causes toxic side effects. <b8_0>Immunosuppressive drugs<b8_0/> such as <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2>cyclosporin<a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> prevent T cells from responding to signals correctly by inhibiting signal transduction pathways.
